tips.tip: MAC culture results take 2-8 weeks to grow because NTM are slow-growing bacteria. Fast, molecular tests (PCR, gene sequencing) exist but are still in development for NTM since it's a rare disease with diverse strains. Labs won't declare a sample negative until 8 weeks have passed. The higher your bacterial load, the faster results appear - some patients see positive results in 1-2 weeks, while others wait 6-8 weeks. Sensitivity testing (which antibiotics work) takes an additional 7-21 days after bacteria grow.
tips.notes: Sue Sherek explained PCR limitations. Mamie Balestra confirmed 8-week standard. Culture time varies: 2 weeks (Karen Povey), 45 days (Jo Ann Kiemen), 2 months typical.

tips.tip: Use multiple techniques to produce sputum samples if you struggle: (1) Nebulize 2 vials of 7% hypertonic saline back-to-back (more effective than single vial), (2) Use Autogenic Drainage app (free) during or after nebulizing - game changer for many patients, (3) Apply warm compresses to chest/back for 30 minutes before airway clearance, (4) Take 600mg guaifenesin 30 minutes before, (5) Use postural drainage positions (hips elevated with yoga block or wedge pillow), (6) Combine Aerobika with mask instead of mouthpiece, (7) Try early morning collection when production is highest.
tips.notes: Lavinia Krufka's full 40-minute protocol. Multiple patients confirmed 2 vials > 1 vial. Autogenic Drainage app repeatedly mentioned as breakthrough. Some patients with EDS/connective tissue disorders find forced coughing particularly difficult.

tips.tip: For sputum induction at a clinic: expect 9% hypertonic saline nebulized through a mask in a chamber with pulse oximeter monitoring. This produces samples faster than home collection but uses higher saline concentration. If your sample is rejected as 'contaminated with epithelial cells from throat,' wait 1 hour after eating, drinking (even water), or brushing teeth before producing next sample. Hospital/clinic oxygen nebulizers finish in <10 minutes vs 30 minutes at home, which may produce less sputum. Request mouthpiece instead of mask if mask doesn't fit properly.
tips.notes: Tracy Biediger's disappointing sputum induction experience. Mayo Clinic used 9% saline. NJH contamination prevention guidelines: 1-hour wait after eating/drinking. Ill-fitting masks reduce effectiveness.

tips.tip: Current standard is typically ONE sputum sample per testing session (monthly or quarterly), not three consecutive days like older protocols required. For diagnosis in 2015 and before, three consecutive samples were standard, but most physicians now order single samples every 3 months during treatment and monitoring. However, if producing sample is difficult or you want to increase accuracy, collect sputum two consecutive mornings in the same container (refrigerate between collections) or use two separate containers.
tips.notes: Carol Wiegmann questioned change from 3-sample to 1-sample protocol. Multiple patients confirmed 1 sample now standard. Thomas Jefferson University (partnered with NJH) uses 1-sample protocol. Two-day collection option for difficult producers.

tips.tip: Mail sputum samples to NJH using USPS Priority Mail Express with the biological materials envelope they provide. Costs range from $28-42 depending on location (vs $100+ for FedEx). NJH accepts samples up to 4-5 days after collection, so overnight shipping isn't always necessary - 2-day shipping works. USPS has money-back guarantee if delivery is late, so save tracking number and request refund if it doesn't arrive on promised date. Mail on Monday to avoid weekend delays. Place NJH's pre-packaged materials inside USPS Priority Express flat rate envelope - postal workers accept it when you tell them it contains sputum.
tips.notes: Multiple costs reported: $28.75 (Florida), $35.50 (Arkansas), $39 (various), vs $100 FedEx. Debbie Breslawsky uses regular Priority Mail ($10, 3 days from CT/CA). Sunny Duncanson got refunds twice for late deliveries. FedEx/UPS refuse without prepaid labels.

tips.tip: Culture conversion on Arikayce varies widely: some patients convert in 2-3 months, others take 9-14 months or don't convert at all. Laurel Eiler converted after 2 months (April-June 2023) and stayed negative. Inga B converted after 15 months and remains negative 4 years later. Charlotte Hart converted at 3 months but tested positive again 4 months later. Culture conversion is just one marker - CT scans may not show improvement even when cultures are negative, and some patients have negative sputum but positive bronchoscopy results. Continue monitoring quarterly even after conversion.
tips.notes: Wide variability in conversion times and durability. Nell Conti had negative sputum but worsening CT and positive bronchoscopy. Renee McMillan had mixed results over 14 months. NTM is 'sly' - Charlotte Hart's experience.

tips.tip: When sputum shows 'few' Pseudomonas aeruginosa, treatment approach varies by doctor. British Thoracic Society 2019 guidelines recommend 14 days minimum antibiotics for bronchiectasis patients, with aggressive treatment for new/first infections to attempt eradication (14 days oral Cipro/Levofloxacin or IV meropenem plus 3 months inhaled colistin). However, many doctors just monitor 'few' results unless symptoms worsen. Pseudomonas is very difficult to eradicate once established - some patients test positive repeatedly despite multiple treatment rounds. Request sensitivity testing to determine which antibiotics work best for your strain.
tips.notes: Janet Wilson researched British guidelines after doctor didn't treat 'few' result. Caroline Nixon recommends aggressive early treatment. Joan Byrne's doctor monitors 'few' without treatment. Bonnie Sharp tested positive repeatedly despite treatment. Levofloxacin severe side effects common (tendon damage, nightmares, joint pain).

tips.tip: Nasty-tasting or discolored (green/yellow) sputum can indicate bacterial infection even without fever, increased cough, or feeling sick. This is often routine bacterial infection (not NTM or Pseudomonas) that responds quickly to antibiotics. However, acid reflux can also cause nasty-tasting sputum. If taste changes persist, collect a sample for culture testing for MAC, routine bacteria, and fungus to get proper diagnosis rather than guessing.
tips.notes: Lavinia Krufka and Harry Berman both experienced infections without typical symptoms. Green color usually indicates bacteria. Rapid improvement with antibiotics suggests routine bacterial infection.

tips.tip: Coinfections in sputum cultures (E. coli, Klebsiella, Pseudomonas, Candida) are not uncommon with NTM/bronchiectasis. E. coli in lungs typically results from aspiration due to esophageal dysmotility or GERD, not from drinking water contamination. Treatment cycles may clear infection temporarily (feeling normal for 1-2 months) but bacteria often returns, requiring repeated antibiotic courses. Levofloxacin appears most effective for E. coli lung infections. If you have swallowing issues or feel food 'taking extra time to go down,' mention this to your doctor - it may explain lung bacteria.
tips.notes: Juli Geddings had 13 rounds of antibiotics for E. coli since Dec 2022. Esophageal manometry and barium swallow revealed dysmotility. Levofloxacin most effective (felt normal for 1-2 months each time). Emma Biggs had E. coli + MAC + candida in bronchoscopy.

tips.tip: Sputum culture results can appear inconsistent because: (1) Not all samples are 'good samples' - if insufficient deep lung sputum or mostly saliva, you get false negatives, (2) Different NTM species may appear in different samples while others disappear, (3) You can be colonized without active infection, so bacteria appear intermittently, (4) One sample represents only what's in that specific sputum at that time, not everything in your lungs, (5) Treatment may clear colonies without completely eradicating bacteria, which resurface later. This is why doctors want regular multiple samples over time - one negative doesn't prove absence.
tips.notes: Lavinia Krufka explained sample quality issues. Lori Baycar (pulmonary/ID patient since 2008) explained colonization vs infection, treatment effects, and normal variation. Bill Renner had 3 samples showing 3 different NTM species. M. mageritense often from water.

tips.tip: Large mucus plugs (1 inch wide or larger) that you cough up are actually a positive sign that airway clearance is working, though the experience can be scary. Green/yellow color indicates possible bacterial infection worth culturing. If you're coughing up large plugs regularly, consider that twice-daily airway clearance with hypertonic saline may prevent these dramatic coughing events by keeping mucus moving continuously. Bronchoscopy can be therapeutic for clearing plugs in lower lobes that are difficult to reach with postural drainage and PEP devices.
tips.notes: Norrie Robbins: 1-inch wide, 0.5-inch long green glob after using Airphysio. Cecilia Peabody recommended culture for green/yellow sputum. Julia Venuti discussed mucus plugs in bronchoscopy reports. Samantha Lane explained HS prevents dramatic events.

tips.tip: You do NOT need to be an established NJH patient to have your doctor send sputum samples to NJH's microbiology lab for culture - any doctor can request NJH lab testing, though your local lab must forward the sample with doctor's authorization. There may be a patient charge for the forwarding. However, the Home Sputum Collection program (sending samples directly from home) is only available to established NJH patients. If you have an appointment scheduled, you can provide your first sample even before your first visit, but it must go through local lab channels.
tips.notes: Debbie Breslawsky and Lavinia Krufka clarified requirements. Sally Wilson sent sample before first NJH appointment (through local lab). Home collection program requires government approval for direct patient mailing - not yet widely available.

tips.tip: Professional sputum induction by respiratory therapists varies dramatically in helpfulness. Some RTs expect immediate sample production using equipment that doesn't work well (ill-fitting masks, brief saline sessions), while others provide hands-on assistance with percussion, vibration, breathing techniques, and postural drainage. Many RTs cite infection control concerns and won't help produce samples. If your first RT isn't helpful, try others - Mary Hinsen visited three RTs before finding one who worked for her individually. Online videos, the Autogenic Drainage app, and patient forum tips may be more useful than rushed clinical sputum induction.
tips.notes: Tracy Biediger disappointed by RT who just handed her container with no guidance. Anonymous user: RTs refused to help due to infection exposure risk. Mary Hinsen: third RT finally effective with percussion, vibration, box breathing. NJH RT told patient 'we don't teach Autogenic Drainage anymore' despite its effectiveness.

key_insights: Sputum culture timing is variable by design - NTM's slow growth means waiting 6-8 weeks for negative results, but positive results can appear anywhere from 1 week (high bacterial load) to 8 weeks (low load).
The shift from 3-sample to 1-sample protocols reflects practical changes in medical practice, but multi-day collection may still be valuable for difficult producers to increase diagnostic accuracy.

Culture results appear inconsistent not because testing is unreliable, but because one sputum sample represents a snapshot of what's actively moving out of lungs at that moment - this is why regular monitoring over months/years is essential.

Producing adequate sputum samples is one of the hardest challenges for many NTM patients, especially those with connective tissue disorders - success often requires combining multiple techniques (2 saline vials, Autogenic Drainage app, postural drainage, warm compresses, guaifenesin).
USPS Priority Express is dramatically cheaper than FedEx/UPS for mailing sputum to NJH ($28-42 vs $100+), and NJH's 4-5 day acceptance window means 2-day shipping is usually sufficient.

Coinfections (Pseudomonas, E. coli, Klebsiella, Candida) are common in NTM/bronchiectasis lungs and may cause symptoms or require treatment independent of NTM status - culture for routine bacteria and fungus, not just AFB.

Culture conversion on Arikayce varies from 2-15 months, and negative cultures don't always correlate with CT scan improvement - some patients have negative sputum but positive bronchoscopy, highlighting the limitations of sputum testing alone.

Professional sputum induction help is inconsistent - many RTs can't or won't provide hands-on assistance, making self-taught techniques from patient community often more practical than clinical services.

Levofloxacin side effects (tendon damage, nightmares, severe joint pain, muscle weakness) are common and serious enough that many patients can no longer tolerate this first-line Pseudomonas treatment.

common_questions.question: How long does it take to get sputum culture results back?
common_questions.answer: MAC and other NTM cultures take 2-8 weeks because these bacteria grow very slowly. Some patients see positive results in 1-2 weeks if bacterial load is high, but labs won't declare a sample truly negative until 8 weeks have passed. After bacteria grows, sensitivity testing (which antibiotics work) takes an additional 7-21 days. Fast molecular tests (PCR, gene sequencing) exist but aren't yet standard for NTM due to the disease's rarity and diversity of strains.

common_questions.question: I can't produce any sputum for testing - what techniques actually work?
common_questions.answer: Try combining multiple techniques: (1) Nebulize 2 vials of 7% hypertonic saline back-to-back instead of one, (2) Download the free Autogenic Drainage app and use it during or right after nebulizing - many patients say this is a game changer, (3) Apply warm compresses or heating pads to chest and back for 30 minutes before airway clearance, (4) Take 600mg guaifenesin 30 minutes before, (5) Use postural drainage with hips elevated on yoga block or wedge pillow, (6) Try early morning when mucus production is highest. It takes some patients 40 minutes to produce enough for a sample even with all these techniques.

common_questions.question: My doctor wants only one sputum sample but I thought you needed three consecutive days?
common_questions.answer: Medical practice has changed. The three consecutive sample protocol was standard through 2015 for diagnosis, but most physicians now order just one sample for routine monitoring every 3 months during treatment and follow-up. However, if you want to increase accuracy or have trouble producing samples, you can collect sputum over two consecutive mornings in the same container (refrigerate between) or use two separate containers. The single-sample approach appears sufficient for most patients when done regularly over time.

common_questions.question: What's the cheapest way to mail sputum samples to National Jewish Health?
common_questions.answer: Use USPS Priority Mail Express ($28-42 depending on your location) instead of FedEx ($100+). NJH accepts samples up to 4-5 days after collection, so 2-day shipping usually works fine - overnight isn't necessary. Place NJH's biological materials package inside a USPS Priority Express flat rate envelope. Mail on Monday to avoid weekend delays. Save your tracking number because USPS has money-back guarantee - if delivery is late, you can get a full refund by filling out a simple online form. Multiple patients have successfully gotten refunds when deliveries were delayed by one day.

common_questions.question: Why do my culture results keep changing - one test shows one bacteria, next test shows something different?
common_questions.answer: This is normal and doesn't mean testing is unreliable. One sputum sample represents only what's actively moving out of your lungs at that moment, not everything that's in there. Different NTM species can appear and disappear between samples. You can be colonized with bacteria (present but not causing active infection) so they show up intermittently. Sometimes samples aren't 'good' samples - if you didn't produce deep lung sputum but mostly saliva, you get false negatives. This is exactly why doctors want regular testing over months and years - one negative doesn't prove absence, and one positive doesn't tell the whole story.

common_questions.question: How long after starting Arikayce does it take to achieve culture conversion?
common_questions.answer: It varies widely from 2 months to 15+ months, and not everyone converts. Some patients converted in 2-3 months and stayed negative for years. Others took 9-14 months. Some patients converted then became positive again months later. Some never achieved conversion despite extended treatment. Culture conversion is just one marker - your CT scans may not improve even when cultures turn negative, and some patients have negative sputum samples but positive bronchoscopy results. Continue quarterly monitoring even after conversion since NTM can return.

common_questions.question: My culture shows 'few' Pseudomonas aeruginosa - do I need treatment?
common_questions.answer: Treatment approach varies by doctor. British Thoracic Society guidelines recommend aggressive treatment for first/new Pseudomonas infections (14 days Cipro or Levofloxacin, or IV meropenem plus 3 months inhaled colistin) to attempt eradication. However, many doctors just monitor 'few' results unless you develop symptoms. Pseudomonas is very difficult to eradicate once established - some patients test positive repeatedly despite multiple treatment rounds. Request sensitivity testing to see which antibiotics work for your strain. Be aware that Levofloxacin has serious side effects (tendon damage, nightmares, joint pain) that affect many patients.

common_questions.question: Does nasty-tasting sputum mean I have an infection?
common_questions.answer: Often yes, but not always. Nasty-tasting or green/yellow sputum usually indicates bacterial infection (often routine bacteria, not NTM) even if you have no fever, increased cough, or feel sick. These infections typically respond quickly to antibiotics. However, acid reflux can also cause nasty-tasting sputum without infection. The best approach: collect the sample and send for culture testing for MAC, routine bacteria, and fungus so you get proper diagnosis rather than guessing.

common_questions.question: Can I send my sputum to National Jewish Health if I'm not a patient there?
common_questions.answer: Your doctor can request NJH lab testing even if you're not an established NJH patient, but the sample must go through your local lab - they forward it to NJH with doctor's authorization. You may be charged for the forwarding. The Home Sputum Collection program (mailing samples directly from home) is only available to established NJH patients. If you have an upcoming NJH appointment scheduled, you can provide a sample before your first visit, but it still must go through local lab channels.

common_questions.question: I coughed up a huge mucus plug - is this dangerous?
common_questions.answer: Large mucus plugs (1 inch or larger) that you cough up are actually a positive sign that airway clearance is working, though the experience can be scary and uncomfortable. Green or yellow color suggests possible bacterial infection worth culturing. These dramatic coughing events often happen when you've successfully dislodged built-up mucus. Twice-daily airway clearance with hypertonic saline helps prevent large plugs from forming by keeping mucus moving continuously. If plugs are in lower lobes beyond reach of home clearance, bronchoscopy can be therapeutic for removal.
